I like this! 
However, why do we have to stick to Humor-Sans? There are lots of free handwritten-style Fonts out there which supports lowercase letters (I am aware that original xkcd uses captials only)! There might be even some fonts which support unicode too! The current limitations (capital only, no unicode) might result in some irritation by standard users.
So maybe it is better to follow @Carreau's advide and include this feature as an easter-egg hidden in the depth of IPython :smile:

Humor Sans was chosen because that is the font that matplotlib uses for its
xkcd mode and it was designed to match the xkcd hand-drawn chars.  Of
course, another hand drawn font could be used, but I don't think I would
call it "xkcd" mode.

Cheers,

Brian

I think that the xkcd mode is nice as an easter eggs, but IMHO a custom styling should not be done with injecting CSS through a ipython display-html.

This **will** break the notebooks in future versions as we **will** change the name of the css classes. One [can](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/urls/raw.github.com/Carreau/posts/master/02-css-selector.ipynb) write an extension that apply Theme to a notebook, store this theme name in the metadata ans update the style while nbviewer/ipython  are upgraded without changing the content of the notebook.

Added point on hangout. I still feel that this should be more hidden, it is a nice eastereggs but: 
- we won't support it.
- the implementation will give bad idea to peoples.

What won't we support it?  I surely will.  The code is trivial and will be easy to keep updated.

Why is this giving people a bad idea?  One of my main goals with this work is to help people to realize how easy it is to style notebooks. I realize we need to stablize our CSS classes, but that is true of the entire notebook - but that shouldn't prevent us from encouraging users to do cool crazy things.  In fact, we _want_ people to use our unstable APIs - it helps us figure out what they should look like when they stabelize.

But not by injecting css in an HTML tag. it is not the right way to do it. People will ask why it does not work on nbconvert in their pdf, and so on and so forth.

Have you looked at my blog post with the css theme selector ? this allow the CSS to be updated independently of IPython and allow people to disable it.

If I receive a notebook with xkcd mode how do I disable it ? I can't except by deleting the cell. and maybe there are other valuable info in this cell.

This is why I was proposing to hack using display javascript so that it works **only** if someone **run** this code.
If you want to include it in nbviewer, I'll add the option on it after 1.0 to read the notebook metadata.css, but with an option to disable.

This is awesome, and I'm totally in favor of user doing things like that.
And as an IPython user I would use it. 

Nonetheless I fell this goes against the usual politics which is to do things 
the right way, even if it takes time. Applying style to notebooks with a magic (of function)
implies reading a css style from a file on the kernel, to send it to a frontend, and
specifically the notebook (and nbconvert/viewer but let's forget that). 

This is typically a magic which is purely frontend specific and do not care about
the fact that you could be talking to many clients.

It is 100% only availlable in python, but it is definitively something that
should be language agnostic.( you should be able to do it even without kernel)

I feel like by making this as it is, you are either:
- telling people to use it.
- or telling them that you do not always take time to do things the right way (opposite of what we say usually).

This is not by itself the fact that this is probably not the right way to do it. But also and mainly the fact that
you want to have it in the core to **showcase** it.

If I had to have stuff like that in the core, it would not by styling, but more 
the notebook import-hook of @minrk or the ability to run a notebook headless.

Anyway, during next week I'll probably write a thing about theming and how it could be done, maybe
an IPEP.

> This is exactly the kind of interface that I would like to see exposed for
> other people who are less expert at such things. Even if with the caveat

I totally understand, but IMHO this adds confusion on how the notebook works.
it is exactly like thoses example with url and `files/` prefix where people get confused 
when server and kernel are (or not) on the same machine.

Some thoughts:

Some days ago I proposed a PR https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/3581 which essentially open the possibility to add a custom.css in the same directory where the final nbconverted html (full_html or reveal) lives to easily changes some specific css.

I think we can use the same approach here... in this way, we are not passing through the kernel... we only open a space that can be filled or not with a custom.css (custom_style.css if you want), and it is language independent, you can use different styles for different notebooks, we just need to add:

`<link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ static_url("custom_style.css") }}" type="text/css" />`

in the notebook.html template and serve the directory containing the notebook, for example with a xkdc profile:

`c.NotebookApp.extra_static_paths = [u'/path/where/lives/your/notebook']`

I think this solution (I tested and it works great!) is a cleaner and a simpler way to achieve the same xkdc-style (or whatever style) and to avoid some of problems discussed by @Carreau.
If you are interested in this approach, I can make the PR and we can discuss about that in more detailed way...

Cheers.

Damián
